isis.stitle: Recall 98505 - Tie Rod Arm Fracture on Fabco Front Drive Axles

recall.subject: Tie Rod Arm Fracture on Fabco Front Drive Axles

defect.para: The tie rod arm can fracture from the spindle yoke due to excessive loads placed on the casting. A failure of the tie rod arm can result in the loss of steering control to the right wheel that could cause a vehicular accident resulting in property damage or personal injury, or both.
Models involved are 4800 4x4s and 4900 6x6s with 12,000 lb. Fabco front drive axles built from 4/1/92 through 4/30/95.

Navistar will notify the involved vehicle owners of this campaign. A listing of owner names and addresses has been furnished to the involved dealers to enable them to follow up with this recall campaign. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcprocinfo.para: This recall involves two general areas of instruction as follows:

item.para: Remove and replace the Spindle Yokes and tie rod adjuster, which will include toe in and wheel stop adjustment.
Vehicle poppet re-adjustment for steering gear. Instructions provided in kit.

note.para: Prepare a clean place to work. It is important that no dirt or foreign material be allowed to enter the unit during repairs. The outside of the unit should be carefully cleaned before starting disassembly.

step1.para: Block the rear wheels.
Raise the front of the truck with a jack and support with jackstands of suitable capacity.

warning.para: A jack must never be used alone to support vehicle while under chassis service is being performed. The jack may lower and serious personal injury could result. Always support vehicle with floor stands.

step1.para: Remove the front wheels.

note.para: Follow all procedures for working with brake material dust. OSHA standards should be consulted with respect to mandatory requirements as well as for suggested procedures to minimize exposure. (Reference: Title 29, Code of Federal Regulations, Section 1910.1001.)

step1.para: Remove the brake drum.
Remove the eight outer drive flange locknuts.
Remove the large flanged axle locknut.

The drive flange should be loose enough to remove by hand. If it is not, use two 3/8-16 bolts in the extractor holes provided for this purpose. Set the colored drive flange shims aside for reuse during assembly.

caution.para: Remove bearings in a manner that will not damage those bearings as they will be re -used.

step1.para: Remove the wheel-bearing locknut, washer, and adjusting nut from the spindle. Rock the hub lightly to loosen the outer wheel-bearing cone. Remove the cone and wrap it protectively.

Remove the hub, by pulling the assembly straight off to avoid cocking the inner bearing cone ( Figure 1). If the cone binds against the spindle, try lightly rocking the hub to free it. Wipe off any oil that may have reached the brake shoe before it reaches the brake lining.
Remove the brake assembly. Refer to GROUP 04-BRAKES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for procedures to remove the foundation brakes.
2. Remove the ten 5/8" locknuts which secure the spindle and the dust shield /brake spider assembly. Remove the spindle ( Figure 2).
Carefully remove the axle shaft by withdrawing it from the differential through the spindle yoke.
Remove the tie rod end. Remove the tie rod adjuster link, from the tie rod and discard the old adjuster.
Install new adjuster between tie rod end and tie rod.

Loosen the upper kingpin adjusting screw jam nut and back out the adjusting screw until the spindle yoke stops moving downward and is resting on the suspension yoke. Remove the four 3/4" steering arm or upper kingpin cap locknuts, and pull the arm or cap up off its mounting studs. If difficulty is encountered, turn the adjusting screw back in to force the arm or cap off the studs ( Figure 3).

Using Fabco tool number 866-0687-007 ( refer to CTS-5149 page 28) or equivalent, loosen the lower kingpin locknut and completely remove the locknut, lock washer and lower kingpin ball stud from the spindle yoke.
Remove the 7/8" upper kingpin bolt and its locknut and two attendant washers from the suspension yoke.

Use Fabco special tool number 866 706 or equivalent (refer to CTS-5149 page 27). Refer to Figure 4, to pull the upper kingpin ball stud from the suspension yoke. The tool is available from Fabco, or it can be fabricated. Do not try to remove the ball stud by rocking the spindle yoke as this may affect the critical press fit between the ball stud and suspension yoke. Fit the tool's two tubes over two diagonally located steering arm or upper kingpin cap studs. Insert the 1 " - 14 bolt through the washer and the tool's central hole and start it in the threads in the top of the upper kingpin ball stud. Tighten the bolt until the ball stud is pulled free of the suspension yoke.
Remove the tool, grasp the spindle yoke at the top, and rotate it outward and down to disengage it from the suspension yoke.

Screw the lower kingpin ball stud into the new spindle yoke until the top of the threaded portion is flush with the inside surface of the yoke. Ensure that the locating pin for the kingpin lockwasher is in position in the yoke, then loosely install the lockwasher and new nut (do not engage the locating pin into the lockwasher at this time).

Smear the spherical portion of the lower kingpin ball stud and seal with chassis grease. Grasping the spindle yoke with both hands, place the lower ball stud into its bearing in the suspension yoke. Rotate the top of the spindle yoke over the upper suspension yoke.

Smear chassis grease in the upper kingpin bearing and seal and start the upper ball stud through the bearing and into its bore in the suspension yoke. Place one upper kingpin washer on the upper kingpin bolt and insert the bolt up through the suspension yoke and upper kingpin ball stud. Install the other washer and the 7/8" locknut on the bolt and tighten to 500 ft-lbs. (678 Nm).

After wiping both mounting surfaces clean of grease, push the steering arm or upper kingpin cap down over its mounting studs, install the four 3/4" nuts, and tighten to 250 ft-lbs. (339 Nm). Make sure the top king pin adjusting screw is still backed out.

Slowly tighten the upper kingpin adjusting screw until upward motion of the spindle yoke stops. If a finger is placed near the gap between the suspension and spindle yokes, the point at which upward travel stops can be determined. Significant additional resistance will also be felt in the effort required to turn the adjusting screw.

Fill the gap between the suspension and spindle yokes in the area of the lower kingpin ball stud with a stack of feeler gauges. There should be enough gauges in the stack to fit the gap snugly ( Figure 5).
Tighten the lower kingpin ball stud until the feeler gauge stack loosens, indicating that the ball stud threads are actually beginning to spread the suspension and spindle yokes apart.
Loosen the lower kingpin ball stud just enough to allow the closest hole in the lower kingpin lockwasher to engage the retaining dowel pin. Tighten the locknut to 600 ft-lbs. (813 Nm).
Back out the upper kingpin adjusting screw 1/16 turn and tighten the jam nut to 45 ft-lbs. (61 Nm), while holding the adjusting screw from turning.

Insert the tip of the axle shaft carefully through the inner axle seal and continue to push the assembly in until it can be felt to contact the differential. Rotate the assembly, so the yoke shaft mounting faces are horizontal. By using a bar placed between the universal joint and the yoke shaft as a lever, the tip of the axle shaft inside the housing can be raised sufficiently to allow it to engage with the differential splines ( Figure 6).
Lubricate the bearing's inner surface, and pack the cavity between bearing and seal with wheel bearing grease.
Slide the spindle over the axle shaft and spindle yoke studs. The large keyway must be located at the 12 o'clock position.

Install the dust shield/brake spider assembly onto the spindle yoke studs with the large hole positioned to receive the air chamber mounting bracket. Install the ten 5/8" locknuts and tighten to 175 ft-lbs. (237 Nm).
Re-install the tie rod and tighten the castle nut to 100 ft-lbs. (136 Nm), and install a new cotter pin.

svcsubproc.title: Re-install Brake Assembly
svcsubproc.para: Refer to GROUP 04-BRAKES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for procedures to install the foundation brakes.

svcsubproc.title: Wheel Bearings, Hub, and Brake Drum

step1.para: Lightly coat the outer surface of the spindle with grease to reduce the chance of the inner wheel bearing cocking upon installation of the hub.

Grasping the outer circumference of the hub at the 12 and 6 o'clock positions, push the hub straight on to the spindle. If difficulty is encountered, try rocking the hub slightly to free the inner bearing.
Install the outer bearing and adjusting nut.

Tighten the bearing adjusting nut to 50 ft-lbs. (68 Nm) while simultaneously rotating the hub assembly. Loosen the nut and repeat this procedure 2-3 times to ensure that the bearings are seated properly. After the final tightening, back off the nut 1/8 turn ( Figure 7).

Install the wheel bearing lockwasher. If the lockwasher doesn't engage the dowel pin retainer, back off the adjusting nut just enough to allow its dowel pin to engage in the lockwasher's closest hole. Install and tighten the locknut to 400 ft-lbs. (542 Nm).
The wheel bearing end play should be checked with a dial indicator as part of the adjustment procedure. The correct end play is.002" to .004" (0.05 to 0.10mm).

Install all removed drive flange shims and drive flange over the drive studs. Install the 8 drive flange locknuts and tighten to 100 ft-lbs. (136 Nm). Install and tighten the large flanged axle locknut to 400 ft-lbs. (542 Nm).
Mount the brake drum over the wheel studs.
Re-install wheel assembly and torque wheel nuts to 450-500 ft-lbs.
Grease all lubrication points before returning the vehicle to service.
Replace the other front axle spindle yoke using these instructions. After both spindle yokes have been replaced, it will be necessary to adjust toe-in and front axle wheel stops.

svcsubproc.title: Toe-In Adjustment
svcsubproc.para: To adjust toe-in, rotate the tie rod adjuster until 1/16" + or - 1/16" is achieved. After adjustment, tighten both tie rod adjuster clamp bolts to 75 ft-lbs. (102 Nm). Refer to Figure 8.

note.para: Toe-in must be correctly adjusted before performing this procedure. The inside wheel turning should be 35 degrees. To adjust, loosen the steering stop jam nut on the rear of the spindle yoke and adjust with the 12 point adjusting screw. After adjustment, tighten the jam nut to 75 ft-lbs. (102 Nm).

svcproc.title: On-Vehicle End of Travel Poppet Re-Adjustment Procedures for TAS Steering Gears

step1.para: Start the engine, and allow the vehicle to idle for 5-10 minutes to warm the hydraulic fluid. Shut off the engine.

Remove the new poppet adjusting screw and nut from kit # 8900066R91. Turn the screw into the non-sealing end of the jam nut until the drive end of screw is flush with the nut. Your steering gear will have either a fixed stop bolt or an adjusting screw (Navistar production is a fixed stop bolt, however, if the poppets have ever been reset it will have an adjusting screw.). Refer to Figure 9.

Make sure the engine is off and the road wheels are in straight ahead position. Remove and discard the poppet fixed stop bolt (if equipped) and washer (if equipped) from the lower end of housing. If the unit has a poppet adjusting screw and sealing nut, remove and discard them. Refer to Figure 10.

figure.caption: Remove Poppet Adjusting Screw and Sealing Nut

para.emph: Turn adjusting screw assembly into housing

step1.para: Turn the adjusting screw and sealing nut assembly, without rotating the nut on the screw, into the housing until the nut is firmly against the housing using a 7/32" allen wrench. Tighten the sealing nut against the housing. Refer to Figure 11.

figure.caption: Turn Adjusting Screw and Sealing Nut Assembly

step1.para: Refill system reservoir with approved hydraulic fluid. Refer to Figure 12.

caution.para: Do not mix fluid types. Mixing of transmission fluid, motor oil, or other hydraulic fluids will cause seals to deteriorate faster.

step1.para: Place a jack under the center of the front axle and jack up the front end of the vehicle so the steer axle tires are off the ground. Refer to Figure 13.

figure.caption: Place Jack Under Center of Front Axle

para.emph: Push Upper Poppet Out to Prepare it for Setting

caution.para: Do not hold the steering wheel at full turn for more than 10 seconds at a time; the heat build-up at pump relief pressure may damage components.

step1.para: Perform the following:

step2.para: Start the engine and let it run at idle speed.
Note which output shaft timing mark is nearest the housing piston bore.
Turn the steering wheel in the direction that makes this timing mark move toward the adjusting screw just installed. Turn in this direction until axle stop contact is made.
Pull hard on the steering wheel (put 30 lbs. rim pull on a 20" dia. steering wheel) after the axle stop is contacted. Refer to Figure 14.

figure.caption: Pull Hard on Steering Wheel After Axle Stop is Contacted

step2.para: Turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction (end of timing mark away from adjusting screw) until the other axle stop is contacted.
Pull hard on the steering wheel (put 30 lbs. rim pull on a 20" dia. steering wheel).
Release the steering wheel and shut off the engine. Refer to Figure 15.

step1.para: Loosen the sealing nut and back out the adjusting screw until 1 " is past the nut. Tighten the sealing nut against the housing. Refer to Figure 16.

step2.para: Start the engine and let it idle.
Turn the steering wheel in the original direction (end of timing mark toward adjusting screw), until axle stop contact is made.

Hold the steering wheel in this position (with 30 lbs. rim pull) for 10 seconds, then release. Repeat this hold and release process as many times as necessary while completing Step 11. Refer to Figure 17.

figure.caption: Hold Steering Wheel in This Position

step2.para: With steering wheel held at full turn, loosen the screw jam nut and hold it in place with a wrench.

Turn the adjusting screw in (clockwise) using finger-pressure only (don't use a ratchet), until the Allen wrench comes to a stop. Do not attempt to turn it in farther. Pause the turning-in process each time the driver releases the steering wheel; continue turning only while the wheel is held at full turn.
Back off the adjusting screw 31/4 turns and tighten the sealing nut. Torque the sealing nut to 33-37 Ibf-ft.

step1.para: The poppets have now been completely reset. Lower the vehicle. Check the reservoir and fill if required.

note.para: The length of the adjusting screw beyond the nut must be no more than 1 1/16" for proper thread engagement.
The length of adjusting screw beyond the sealing nut may be different for each vehicle.

partsinfo.para: Part number 8900063R91 and 8900064R91 must be ordered via fax. Please use the attached fax form provided in the dealer letter.
Part number 8900066R91 must be ordered using the Recall order form attached to the safety recall via Navistar's PDC's.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location. Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his vehicle as soon as possible.
